@Louboui , Anything left on an exchange (Bitcoin or XRP) is no longer under your control and Coinbase, for example, could decide to freeze your account.

“The consensus mechanism for the Devs and the protocol allows them to make it where they can unilaterally update and lock it” The source code for the XRP Ledger is open. Please point to the code that allows such a thing. You may start here: https:// github.com/ripple/rippled

Incorrect. XRP cannot be locked or frozen. If you choose to leave your crypto on an exchange, Bitcoin or XRP, you’ve handed over your keys and control over that crypto. Coinbase can freeze a user acct, but that is not the same as crying “all BTC can be frozen by Coinbase.”
I don’t think Ripple has an API for XRP payment processing. Anybody can plug into the network for free. You don’t need Ripple’s permission to accept XRP.
Not my issue. I’m glad Ripple has a war chest at its disposal to help make XRP the best damn digital asset in existence.
Every penny that XRP increases = $600 MILLION for Ripple. Nobody has more to gain from XRP appreciating than Ripple.

there are serious points here also: a) it confuses even technical people until they realise you can buy less than one bitcoin b) 0.00000123 is harder to read and think about than 1.23, can easily miscalculate 10x c) two digits after currency unit is more common, bits offers that.
bits is already used in Bitcoin for some years to refer to 1 millionth of a bitcoin or 100 satoshis.
